title.narrative: Lamu East Community Recovery and Rehabilitation (LECR)

description.narrative: Lamu East is inhabited by one of the smallest ethnic groups in Kenya. Since 1976 when the Government of Kenya moved them from their ancestral home, this community continues to face immense livelihood challenges due to multiple socio-economic factors and adverse effects of climate change. The community engages in labor-intensive shifting cultivation which destroys the forests, upon which their very livelihood rain-fed farming is based. Providing them with appropriate planting inputs and facilitating them to access agricultural extension services where successful farmers influence others to adopt best practices. This project will aim at reducing household poverty levels, improve food security, and increase adaptability to disaster risks among community. The main program activities will include promotion of conservation agriculture, support to alternative livelihood strategies, rehabilitation of existing water sources and support to development of community institutions.

Progressive farmers will be selected in each of the groups and supported to establish demonstration farms where other farmers can learn best practices. In partnership with A Language Development Program (ALDP) and Summer Institute of Linguistics or Bible Translation and Literacy, a practical field manual on basic farm practices and ecosystem-based adaptation to climate change will be developed. Runoff from public buildings roof catchment will be harnessed to ensure sufficient water for the selected communities during the dry season. In addition to this, the program will promote hygiene education. The Galla goats program will be initiated as their milk and meat serve as income sources; they are resistant to many diseases and survive in harsh conditions.
